definition: Lasting for a very short time; transitory
etymology: From Greek 'ephēmeros' (ἐφήμερος), meaning 'lasting only a day' — from 'epi' (on) + 'hēmera' (day). Originally used to describe insects that live for only one day.
sentence: Social media stories are ephemeral by design, disappearing after 24 hours.

definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere
etymology: From Latin 'ubique' meaning 'everywhere' — from 'ubi' (where) + '-que' (and, also). Related to theological concept of God's omnipresence.
sentence: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.

definition: Intended for or understood by only a small group with specialized knowledge
etymology: From Greek 'esōterikos' (ἐσωτερικός), meaning 'inner' or 'within' — from 'esō' (within). Originally referred to Aristotle's more difficult works meant only for inner circle students.
sentence: The professor's lecture on quantum mechanics was too esoteric for the general audience.

definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically based on practical considerations
etymology: From Greek 'pragmatikos' (πραγματικός), meaning 'fit for business' — from 'pragma' (deed, act), from 'prassein' (to do). Related to 'praxis' (practice).
sentence: We need a pragmatic solution that works within our budget constraints.

definition: Fluent, persuasive, and expressive in speech or writing
etymology: From Latin 'eloquens', present participle of 'eloqui' (to speak out) — from 'ex-' (out) + 'loqui' (to speak). Same root as 'loquacious' and 'soliloquy'.
sentence: Her eloquent defense of free speech moved the entire courtroom.

definition: Having a harmful effect, especially in a gradual or subtle way
etymology: From Latin 'perniciosus', from 'pernicies' (destruction) — from 'per-' (completely) + 'nex/necis' (death, killing). Same root as 'internecine'.
sentence: The pernicious spread of misinformation undermines public trust in institutions.

definition: To make something bad or unsatisfactory better
etymology: From Latin 'ameliorare', from 'ad-' (to) + 'melior' (better). Related to French 'améliorer'. The root 'melior' also gives us 'meliorate'.
sentence: The new policies aim to ameliorate the housing crisis in urban areas.

definition: To make obscure, unclear, or unintelligible
etymology: From Latin 'obfuscare', from 'ob-' (over) + 'fuscare' (to darken), from 'fuscus' (dark). Literally means 'to darken over' or 'to cloud'.
sentence: Politicians often obfuscate their true intentions with vague language.

definition: To make something clear; to explain
etymology: From Latin 'elucidare', from 'e-' (out) + 'lucidus' (clear, bright), from 'lux' (light). Literally 'to bring light out'. Related to 'lucid' and 'translucent'.
sentence: The diagram helps elucidate the complex relationship between the components.

definition: Carried out with minimal effort or reflection; mechanical
etymology: From Latin 'perfunctorius', from 'perfungi' (to get through with) — from 'per-' (through) + 'fungi' (to perform). Implies doing just enough to 'get through' a task.
sentence: His perfunctory apology did nothing to repair the damaged relationship.

definition: Clear, logical, and convincing
etymology: From Latin 'cogent-', present participle of 'cogere' (to compel) — from 'co-' (together) + 'agere' (to drive). An argument so forceful it 'drives together' agreement.
sentence: She presented a cogent argument that swayed the skeptical investors.

definition: A person who acts obsequiously to gain advantage; a flatterer
etymology: From Greek 'sykophantēs' (συκοφάντης), literally 'fig-shower' — from 'sykon' (fig) + 'phainein' (to show). Originally meant an informer in ancient Athens, possibly one who reported illegal fig exports.
sentence: The CEO surrounded himself with sycophants who never challenged his decisions.

definition: Stubbornly resistant to authority or control
etymology: From Latin 'recalcitrare' (to kick back) — from 're-' (back) + 'calcitrare' (to kick), from 'calx' (heel). Like a horse kicking back against its rider.
sentence: The recalcitrant employee refused to follow the new safety protocols.

definition: Very attentive to detail; concerned with accuracy and precision
etymology: From Latin 'fastidiosus' (disdainful, squeamish), from 'fastidium' (loathing, disgust) — possibly from 'fastus' (arrogance) + 'taedium' (weariness). Originally implied excessive pickiness.
sentence: Her fastidious code reviews caught bugs that others missed.

definition: Using very few words; brief and to the point
etymology: From Greek 'Lakōnikos' (Λακωνικός), meaning 'of Laconia' (Sparta). Spartans were famous for their terse speech. When Philip II threatened 'If I invade, I will destroy you,' Sparta replied: 'If.'
sentence: His laconic reply of 'no' ended the debate instantly.

definition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress
etymology: From Latin 'ostentare' (to display), frequentative of 'ostendere' (to show) — from 'ob-' (before) + 'tendere' (to stretch). Implies stretching out something for all to see.
sentence: The ostentatious mansion seemed out of place in the modest neighborhood.

definition: Experienced through imagined participation in another's experience
etymology: From Latin 'vicarius' (substitute, deputy), from 'vicis' (change, alternation). Same root gives us 'vicar' (one who acts in place of another) and 'vice-' prefix.
sentence: He lived vicariously through his children's athletic achievements.

definition: Understood or implied without being stated explicitly
etymology: From Latin 'tacitus' (silent), past participle of 'tacere' (to be silent). Related to 'taciturn' (habitually silent) and the name 'Tacitus' (the Roman historian).
sentence: There was a tacit agreement among the team to never discuss the failed project.

definition: Unnecessary; more than what is needed
etymology: From Latin 'superfluus', from 'superfluere' (to overflow) — from 'super-' (over) + 'fluere' (to flow). Literally means 'flowing over' the necessary amount.
sentence: The editor removed superfluous adjectives to tighten the prose.

definition: To place side by side for comparison or contrast
etymology: From Latin 'juxta' (near, beside) + French 'poser' (to place), from Latin 'ponere'. A relatively modern word (19th century), combining Latin and French roots.
sentence: The documentary juxtaposes scenes of wealth and poverty to highlight inequality.

definition: Using more words than necessary; wordy
etymology: From Latin 'verbosus', from 'verbum' (word). Same root as 'verb', 'verbal', and 'verbatim'. The '-ose' suffix indicates fullness or abundance (like 'grandiose').
sentence: His verbose writing style made the simple concept confusing.

definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand
etymology: From Latin 'lucidus' (bright, clear), from 'lux' (light). Same root as 'elucidate', 'translucent', and 'Lucifer' (light-bearer). Clarity of thought is likened to brightness.
sentence: Her lucid explanation made the complex algorithm accessible to beginners.

definition: Holding firmly to something; persistent
etymology: From Latin 'tenax' (holding fast), from 'tenere' (to hold). Same root as 'tenant' (one who holds property), 'tenure', and 'tenable'. Implies a grip that won't let go.
sentence: Her tenacious debugging finally uncovered the elusive race condition.

definition: The ability to make good judgments and quick decisions
etymology: From Latin 'acumen' (a point, sharpness), from 'acuere' (to sharpen). Same root as 'acute', 'acupuncture', and 'acuity'. Mental sharpness is likened to a fine point.
sentence: Her business acumen helped the startup navigate multiple funding rounds.

definition: Excessively concerned with minor details or rules; showing off learning
etymology: From Italian 'pedante' (teacher, schoolmaster), possibly from Greek 'paideuein' (to teach), from 'pais' (child). Originally meant a teacher, later gained negative connotation of excessive formality.
sentence: His pedantic insistence on Oxford commas annoyed his colleagues.

definition: To use ambiguous language to conceal the truth or avoid commitment
etymology: From Latin 'aequivocus', from 'aequus' (equal) + 'vox' (voice). Literally 'equal voice' — saying things that could be taken equally either way. Related to 'equivocal'.
sentence: The politician equivocated when asked about her stance on the controversial bill.

definition: To make a problem, bad situation, or feeling worse
etymology: From Latin 'exacerbare', from 'ex-' (thoroughly) + 'acerbus' (harsh, bitter). Related to 'acerbic' (sharply bitter). Originally meant to irritate or embitter.
sentence: Adding more features will only exacerbate the technical debt problem.

definition: To accept something reluctantly but without protest
etymology: From Latin 'acquiescere' (to find rest in) — from 'ad-' (to) + 'quiescere' (to rest), from 'quies' (rest, quiet). Implies accepting something to achieve peace. Related to 'quiet'.
sentence: After much debate, the team acquiesced to the client's design requests.

definition: Unwilling to change one's views or agree; uncompromising
etymology: From Spanish 'los intransigentes', name of an extreme Spanish political party (1873) — from Latin 'in-' (not) + 'transigere' (to come to an agreement), from 'trans-' (through) + 'agere' (to drive).
sentence: The intransigent stakeholder refused to budge on the deadline despite the team's concerns.

definition: Having knowledge of events before they take place
etymology: From Latin 'praescient-', from 'praescire' (to know beforehand) — from 'prae-' (before) + 'scire' (to know). Same root as 'science', 'conscious', and 'omniscient'.
sentence: Her prescient investment in renewable energy paid off decades later.
